Award.AwardTitle: Regulation of Protein Phosphatase 2A Activity in Arabidopsis by the RCN1 Protein
Award.AbstractNarration: Like animals, plants produce a number of substances that regulate growth and coordinate developmental transitions and responses to environmental signals. Ethylene gas is one such regulator of the plant life cycle, playing important roles in fruit ripening, pathogen defenses and the regulation of cell expansion. Because overall plant form is determined largely by the degree and directionality of cell expansion, ethylene is a crucial regulator of morphology, and ethylene production must be maintained at low levels during phases of rapid cell expansion, such as early seedling growth. Recent work has identified molecular mechanisms that program the degradation of specific enzymes required for ethylene synthesis; this degradation plays a key role in controlling ethylene production. The PI's group previously identified a highly conserved protein phosphatase complex that regulates degradation of ethylene-producing enzymes through dephosphorylation (the process of removing phosphoryl modifications from specific target proteins, or substrates). This project will use genetic and biochemical approaches to identify the components of the PP2A complex that are required, as well as the determinants required for recognition of substrate proteins. The project outcomes will lead to better understanding of the mechanisms that maintain optimal levels of hormone production in plants, allowing adaptive growth responses under conditions of environmental stress or pathogen attack as well as during normal development. The project will also provide training for undergraduate students from underrepresented groups and a graduate student. The Arabidopsis genetic stocks produced in this work will be contributed to the Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center (http://abrc.osu.edu/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focuses on defining mechanisms that control production of the plant signaling molecule ethylene. Ethylene signaling is used to cue stress and defense responses as well as major developmental transitions, and therefore controls traits that are crucial in determining crop yield and quality. All plant tissues are capable of producing ethylene via a known biosynthetic pathway, but the mechanisms deployed to allow highly integrative and dynamic control of ethylene production during the plant life cycle are only recently coming to light. One important set of controls involves the stability of a key enzyme in the biosynthetic pathway, ACC synthase or ACS. ACS proteins are subject to proteolytic degradation under normal growth conditions, but their stability can be increased or decreased by post-translational modifications such as reversible protein phosphorylation. This project has analyzed positive and negative inputs mediated by the protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A) family, a versatile hub for cellular signaling that achieves specificity through combinatorial complexity. Members of the PI's laboratory, including undergraduate research interns from under-represented groups, worked to define the connections between PP2A family members and enzymes of the ethylene biosynthetic pathway. Their results indicate that different combinations of PP2A subunits are responsible for negative regulation of type 1 ACS enzymes (which are stabilized by stress signals) and positive regulation of type 2 ACS enzymes (which respond to developmental signals). The PI's laboratory has worked with two excellent programs that foster success of students from minority-serving and/or historically black undergraduate institutions, The Leadership Alliance and the Brown-Tougaloo Partnership, to provide research internships for four undergraduate researchers. In addition, the project has involved undergraduate and graduate researchers from Brown University, as well as an intern from a local high school. 

The findings from this work are that PP2A positively regulates several type 2 ACS isozymes in a similar way, supporting accumulation of these proteins. In contrast, regulation of two stress-responsive type 1 ACS enzymes appears to be quite different, with PP2A playing a much more important role in negative regulation of ACS6 than in controlling ACS2 stability. For ACS6, PP2A affects stability by recognizing and dephosphorylating a small terminal region that follows the enzymatically active domain of the enzyme. Genetic and biochemical analyses have not identified individual regulatory subunits of the phosphatase that are key to negative regulation of ACS6, suggesting that this function may be shared among several different proteins. Analysis of PP2A gene families from an evolutionary perspective suggests that plant PP2A subunits may share relatively broad overlaps in function, but also predicts highly specialized functions for two subfamilies of regulatory subunits.
